headline.main: Doubts Fail to Deter 'The Diet Revolution'

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on renewed popularity of high-fat, high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet promoted by Dr Robert C Atkins in early 1970'; cites lack of studies of diet's long-term results or safety; notes depleting body of stored carbohydrates causes initial loss of water, weight quickly regained with first starchy food eaten; cites risks; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: It was the early 1970's, the heyday of mini-skirts and quick weight-loss schemes, when fashion magazines and celebrity dieters propelled Dr. Robert C. Atkins's ''diet revolution'' into a national phenomenon. His book, ''Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution,'' promoted a high-fat, high-protein diet spurning most carbohydrates. Many nutritionists and public health experts were dismayed, but 10 million Americans were undeterred. Their reliance on labor-saving devices and fast foods had spawned thunder thighs and rendered their waistlines a thing of the past. They made the book a best seller.

headline.main: New Look At Dieting: Fat Can Be A Friend

docs.abstract: Specialists on nutrition, health and obesity say stripping fat from American diet seems to have backfired, with obesity up 50 percent since big push to limit fat took off in 1970's; blame replacement of fat in diet with excessive amounts of carbohydrates; stress importance of limiting total calories in diet and deriving benefits of fats in such foods as avocados, walnuts, salad oil and fatty fish; graph of types of fats in various oils (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Now hear this: avocados, walnuts, salad dressings with oil, sauteed vegetables, fatty fish and some kinds of margarine may be back on the menu for health-conscious Americans, even for those trying to lose weight, if the findings of recent studies are to be believed. For three decades now, Americans have been bombarded with advice to eat less fat for the sake of their hearts and their waistlines. One well-known expert, Dr. Dean Ornish, advocates stripping away all added fats and naturally fatty foods to achieve a diet containing no more than 10 percent of calories from fat, down from the 44 percent typically consumed by Americans in the 1960's and the 34 percent now consumed.

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students explore various nutritional components found in foods to analyze their sources, effects on the human body, and relationship to a healthy diet. Each student researches a different nutritional component and then creates an informative poster incorporating the research.
